title: AB 2687
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. The law also applies to individuals addicted to drugs, except those in approved treatment programs. It is illegal for a person addicted to drugs to drive a vehicle. This does not apply to those in approved treatment programs. Additionally, it is unlawful to drive a commercial vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.04% or higher. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive a vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is present. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. It is also unlawful to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs. Additionally, it is unlawful to drive with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more, which results in bodily injury to another person. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more, causing bodily injury to another person. In any prosecution, if a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood within three hours after driving, it is presumed they were over the limit. It is not necessary to prove a specific violation of the law in proving neglect of duty while driving. It is unlawful to drive a commercial motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, causing bodily injury to another person. Neglecting any duty imposed by law while driving can be proven without showing a specific violation of the law. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle and causes bodily injury to another person. Passenger for hire refers to someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.04% or more alcohol, it is presumed that the person had that amount while driving. It is unlawful to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to another person. This act does not require reimbursement by local agencies as it creates new crimes or infractions.
